The diet can also be associated with a special feeding technique because some animals, especially those with unique physiological or behavioral adaptations, require special methods of feeding that mimic their natural foraging behaviors, enhancing their psychological well-being and physical health.
Reproductive details of animal species include reproductive health and management information that is paramount in zoological settings, especially for conservation breeding programs.
First, the age at which the species is capable of reproducing, which helps in planning breeding programs, is important.
This takes us also to the specific time of year when the animals of that species naturally breed, which can influence how enclosures are managed and when animals are introduced for mating.

Each species has a specific thermal preference based on its natural habitat, which needs to be mimicked in captivity for optimal health.
Humidity levels are vital and important aspect of climate conditions, especially for species from tropical or aquatic environments, as it affects skin health, hydration, and overall comfort.

Ensuring that light cycles (day and night) in the climate conditions of enclosures are consistent with the natural light patterns of an animal's native habitat helps maintain normal circadian rhythms, which are crucial for feeding, sleeping, and reproductive behaviors.
Many species, particularly reptiles, require climate conditions ensuring an exposure to ultraviolet light to synthesize vitamin D3, essential for calcium metabolism.
